title: The most difficult holes in the PGA over the last 5 years.
text:
The PGA Tour is halfway through its 2024 season. From January to August, professional golfers from all over the world compete in tournaments throughout the tour. Each tournament takes place at a golf course with a total of 18 holes lasting a couple of days.
Professional golfers make money off of their winnings at each tournament. Unlike other professional athletes, PGA golfers do not earn a salary. This creates high stakes on the PGA Tour for professionals to win in order to make money.
With a better understanding of the stakes professional golfers compete for, a question is asked. Over the last 5 years, which holes have given the professionals the most trouble on the PGA Tour?
Any of these holes can make or break a professional’s dream of money and a first-place finish.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)

PGA <- read_csv("PGAToughestHoles2024 - Sheet1 (1).csv") |>
  mutate(
    HoleYear = paste(HOLE,COURSE, YEAR)
  )

BadPar4 <- PGA |>
  filter(AVG > 4.3, YARDS < 430) 

BadPar5 <- PGA |>
  filter(AVG > 5.0, YARDS < 550)

BadPar3 <- PGA |>
  filter(AVG > 3.5, YARDS < 230)

BadP4 <- PGA |>
  filter(AVG > 4.6, YARDS < 500)

Bad <- bind_rows(BadPar4,BadPar5,BadPar3, BadP4)

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=PGA, aes(x=YARDS, y=AVG), color="lightgrey") +
  geom_smooth(data=PGA, aes(x=YARDS, y=AVG), method="lm") +
  geom_point(data=Bad, aes(x=YARDS, y=AVG), color="red") +
  geom_text_repel(data=Bad, aes(x=YARDS, y=AVG, label=HoleYear)) +
  labs(
    x="Total Yards", 
    y="Average Score", 
    title="Scorecards Turn Ugly", 
    subtitle="Over the last 5 years, dreams die when professional golfers play these holes.",
    caption="Source: PGATour.com | By Mason Dover"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=12), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









Golfers did not score well on any of these holes. Hole 18 at The Renaissance Club in 2022 became a burden at the tour. Golfers shot almost a full stroke over par at this hole, making it the hardest hole in the 2022 PGA Tour.
Distance plays a role in a hole’s difficulty, but what do those results look like?
Every par puts expectations on the professionals. To win a tournament, golfers need to score low on each hole.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)

PGA <- read_csv("PGAToughestHoles2024 - Sheet1 (1).csv") |>
  mutate(
    HoleYear = paste(HOLE,COURSE, YEAR), 
    Difficulty = AVG - PAR...4
  )

top20 <- PGA |> top_n(20, wt=Difficulty)


ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(data=top20, aes(y=reorder(HoleYear, DBLBOGEY), x=BIRDIE, xend=DBLBOGEY),
    size = 2,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "green",
    colour_xend = "red") +
  labs(
    title="The Top 20 Holes Based on the Difference Between the Scoring Average on the Hole and Par", 
    subtitle = "If <span style = 'color:green;'>birdies</span> are on the left, that's good. If <span style = 'color:red;'>double bogeys</span> are on the right, that's bad.",
    x="Birdies vs Double Bogeys", 
    y="",
    caption="Source: PGATour.com | By Mason Dover"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 11, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )









A hole may have a lot of double bogeys, but that does not mean it is challenging. Some holes, like Oak Hill Country Club’s East Course Hole 6 in 2023, have many birdies and double bogeys in the results.
Golfers struggled on Hole 18 of The Renaissance Club in 2022. Players were unable to score many birdies and ended up shooting a lot more double bogeys. 
Now that distance and score have been determined as factors in difficulty, how can golfers decide which holes are the hardest? 
The location of every hole and the expected par increases the stakes, which can make things difficult as the game goes on.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)

PGA <- read_csv("PGAToughestHoles2024 - Sheet1 (1).csv") |>
  mutate(
    HoleYear = paste(HOLE,COURSE, YEAR), 
    Difficulty = AVG - PAR...4
  )

top10 <- PGA |> top_n(10, wt=Difficulty)

HardTop10 <- top10 |>
  select(HoleYear, PAR...4, AVG, Difficulty)

HardTop10 |>
  gt() |>
    cols_label(
    HoleYear = "PGA Courses",
    PAR...4 = "Par",
    AVG = "Avg"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Challenges in the Back Half",
    subtitle = "Par 4's provide the most difficulty to professional golfers, but a couple par 3's sneak their way into the top 10." 
  ) |>
tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Mason Dover  |  **Source:** PGATour.com")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=15)
     )
  ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
  fmt_percent(
    columns = c(Difficulty),
    decimals = 1
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#98FB98"),
      cell_text(color = "black")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = HoleYear == "17 Ocean Course at Kiawah Island 2021")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#98FB98"),
      cell_text(color = "black")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = HoleYear == "16 Muirfield Village Golf Course 2020")
  )









Challenges in the Back Half


Par 4's provide the most difficulty to professional golfers, but a couple par 3's sneak their way into the top 10.

46.8%



By: Mason Dover | Source: PGATour.com









While some may expect par 5’s to challenge professionals the most, it is the opposite.
With fewer strokes to work with, professionals need to make every shot count. Each hole’s distance also plays a big factor in which club a golfer needs to use. That explains hole 17 at Ocean Course at Kiawah Island in 2021 and hole 16 at Muirfield Village Golf Course in 2020’s difficulty.
Each professional golfer faces adversity on the golf course. There are many challenges on each hole that make or break players. The weather, sand traps and mental pressure are just a few. 
In the next 5 years, these factors will determine which holes cause the most trouble on the PGA Tour.
